The land is stitched in rows of peach trees, a kingdom of fruit that marks its claim as the Peach Capital of the World, a title it wears with a proud humility upon its welcoming sign. The air is thick with the scent of earth and promise, a testament to the toil of those who work its soil. Houses are scattered across the land, standing solitary and watchful with their metal crowns or gray shingles, their distance from the road a testament to the land's purpose. They stand back, granting space for the fields to breathe and grow.

In the heart of Johnston, a lone traffic light sways above the crossroads, casting its red glow upon the handful of stores that gather there. Hong Kong, a modest family-run diner, serves its fare with the warmth of home. Fiesta Mexican and Gary’s, a small burger joint, round out the trifecta of quick eats. The pizzeria, once a staple, now lingers only in memory. Maxwell and Halford Drug, a pharmacy of small stature but great repute, is famous for its Cherry Coca-Cola, a sweet indulgence amid the medicinal shelves. The IGA grocery stands alone in its role, yet many journey to Batesburg-Leesville's Walmart for their bounty, leaving the IGA for the quick necessities.

Dollar General, a bastion of the everyday, hums with life from dawn till dusk. Possibilities Furniture & More sits quietly, a repository of chairs and tables dreamed into being by a woman whose kindness is as much a fixture as the store itself. Her two movers, silent as shadows, bear the weight of new beginnings to doorsteps near and far. Beside it, Clark's Cuts and Kennels tends to the town's creatures with a gentle hand, offering pampering and care in equal measure.

Beyond the reach of the town's center, the doctor and the vet hold their own courts, small yet capable, ready to mend man and beast alike. Johnston Elementary stands as the lone beacon of early education, sending its charges onward to the next town's schools when their time comes. The promise of a new park, a 2.5-acre haven in the making, whispers of future gatherings and laughter, a balm for the absence of theaters and bowling alleys, of playgrounds and promenades.

Johnston is a place you might miss if you blink, a town where time seems to pause, caught in the gentle rhythm of its own making. Yet, for those who know it, it is a place of quiet significance, where the land and its people are entwined in a story as old as the hills themselves.

In a small southern town in Tennessee, I find myself ensconced in a suburb that stretches between two state highways, a connector of sorts, where the flow of traffic ebbs and swells more than I care for. Yet despite this, a quietude blankets the neighborhood, a stillness interrupted only by the familiar rhythms of daily life. Folks here, they don't come and go as they might elsewhere. The faces are known, the names spoken in the same breath as the seasons.

The land is tended with diligence, yards pruned and preened, chores met with a resigned constancy. In the chill of winter, we take to sledding down the hill that slopes from the side street. Our house sits sentinel at the corner, a watchtower from which we observe the daily procession, each vehicle a known entity, each stranger's car noted with a careful eye. Neighbors take to walking, for exercise or company, dogs trotting faithfully beside them. Children wheel about on bicycles, a dance of innocence and laughter.

Work anchors us at home, my wife and I, along with our daughters, sisters of eleven and fourteen years. Our comings and goings are as familiar to the neighborhood as the hum of lawn mowers that sing out from March to October. The trees, remnants of a forest past, cast their shadows, and in the fall, the leaves descend in a rustling avalanche, demanding rake and flame. The scent of their burning is a herald of autumn's reign.

Winter has grown elusive, a fleeting specter, leaving us in the embrace of an extended fall. Our garage, tucked at the back, serves as both a workshop and a window to the world outside. On rare occasions when the front door is summoned, it is a reminder that life persists beyond our own.

Holidays creep in with a quietude, the streets swelling with the return of kin, cars lining the curbs and driveways. Thanksgiving, Mother's Day, Christmas—they come and go, leaving in their wake a deeper silence.

In all of this, there is a contentment, a satisfaction in the familiarity of place. Were it not for the road that cuts through, it might be perfect.

In the midst of the high desert, my neighborhood sits, surrounded by the relentless expanse of dirt and more dirt, an unending sea of brown. It is a place where the sight of a green lawn is a rare spectacle, a testament to the homeowner’s resolve and the depths of their pockets. Back in the 90s, when I first laid my roots here, the houses were scattered and sparse, the land wide and open. It remains much the same today, though new structures creep in, pushing the boundaries of what was once untouched. The desert slowly takes on the guise of a city, a transformation not unfamiliar to many places. Yet, the heart of it remains, with folks who greet you with warmth, a kindness that speaks of simpler times. My corner of this place is blessed with the company of friendly old souls, a sanctuary of sorts.

The stores that line our streets are the usual suspects, Food 4 Less and Smart & Final, their chains stretching far and wide. For the upscale, one must journey beyond the familiar, for Whole Foods and the like are strangers here. Construction thrives in this landscape, the promise of development in every open space, a reminder of change that looms ever present. It unnerves me, this relentless march towards the future. I fled the clamor of the big city once, and I am loath to return. I work in construction, a drywall and T-bar installer by trade, and I find solace in the creatures of this desert land. 

The high desert draws many, enchanted by its stark beauty and the life that clings to its harsh embrace. Its ecosystems are fragile, demanding our respect and understanding. My family has learned to coexist with the wildlife, and my children revel in the pursuit of lizards and desert insects, their laughter echoing under the vast sky. 

Victorville offers its own allure, a gateway for families to taste the desert’s unique flavor. The San Bernardino County Fair, a yearly spectacle, promises a blend of joy and tradition. Nearby, the snow-draped peaks of Wrightwood beckon, a call to winter’s embrace. For those drawn to the tales of the past, the Victor Valley Museum stands, a keeper of stories told through geological specimens and artifacts, a chronicle of Victorville’s journey through time.

When it comes to describing my neighborhood, there's a certain peculiarity in the way it lays itself out in my mind. For most who'd answer such a question, they'd conjure up images of homes and streets and life unfolding in its ordinary ways. But mine is a different story. My neighborhood is the college campus where I dwell, and the souls in my dormitory make up the tapestry of my community. The campus itself, sprawling and indifferent, is the backdrop of this peculiar neighborhood, an extension of its reach, though less intimate.

Yet even in its strange constitution, my neighborhood shares echoes with the neighborhoods of old. It has its houses, its people, its stores, and its parks. Let's speak first of these "houses" that form the skeleton of my abode. The types of dwellings here are varied. There are apartments, true houses, and dormitory halls.

In the apartments, you'll find between two to four souls sharing a room, and each floor holds about four to six such rooms. The buildings rise for two floors typically, housing around twenty individuals. Then there are the houses, scarce and scattered, standing as relics for those tied to the institution, alumni mostly, who rent them out. They are fewer, less efficient in their scarcity. Lastly, the dormitories rise like ancient monoliths, sheltering hundreds of students. Here, two to a room is the rule, with exceptions that prove it, and this is the most common shelter where I lay my head.

Having covered housing, we turn now to the people. My school wears its diversity like a badge, and this is mirrored in the neighborhood's populace. People of every culture and age reside here. The professional staff find their place in the scattered houses, while the dormitories welcome the new arrivals, and the apartments become havens for those who have grown older in this place.

Yet to speak of these people in mere words is to do them a disservice. So let us move to the stores and parks. This self-contained world of my school has its own assortment of stores, a mixture of dining establishments akin to any neighborhood, alongside the unique branding of the school’s own shops for clothing and groceries. Within these bounds, all needs find their fulfillment.

And then there is the park, a sanctuary for all, kept immaculate and safe through the collective efforts of the neighborhood's denizens, a testament to the diverse life that breathes within this peculiar, self-sustaining enclave.

There are no sidewalks in this place. The earth falls away in long sweeping inclines and my house stands at the crest of the steepest hill, a monument to the incline's defiance. The folk around here call it the workout hill, a nod to the sweat and breath of joggers who labor against its grade. On my street, there is no stone path for walking, and folk take to the road. The road is pocked and scarred, a thing of danger underfoot and wheel alike. Wires hang in weblike tangles, their tattered strands a testament to the storms that rage and the arboreal debris that tears them asunder, the scars of their mending etched in patchwork. Tall evergreens stand in solemn watch, casting their shadows long and deep. Yet the people here loathe these ancient sentinels, for they block the ocean's visage. Houses rise high on the hill, glass-fronted monoliths reaching for the bay's distant embrace. Come sunset, the water glows with a fire from beneath, the sky a canvas washed in orange. But clouds, more frequent than not, shroud these visions with their pallor. The days are gray and damp, and a green moss creeps over all things, roofs and cars and railings alike. Once, a month gone by, my car lay untouched, and when I came to it, the moss had claimed it as its own. It took me hours to strip it bare, its surface green and furred. Children are scarce, though a school stands not far away. The folk here are mostly of age, their work behind them. In place of children, there are dogs, a common sight on lawns or in chase down the street. Leave a door unguarded and you may find one in your parlor, as I did, only to shoo it out again. Rabbits roam wild and free, the gardeners their sworn enemies for the burrows and uprooted plants they leave in their wake. My cats, they revel in the hunt, and the rabbits know their days are numbered. Birds flit and flutter, sparrows and hummingbirds in their finery, while hawks and eagles are driven off by the crow's black malice. Stores are absent here, but a trek downhill to the shore reveals eateries where the sea's bounty is served. The beach is but a rocky margin, yet to cast stones into the bay is a joy of sorts. The bay is narrow, and even in the mist, the far shore is clear to the eye.

In the borough of Brooklyn, where the city sprawls out in iron and stone, there lies a neighborhood called Bensonhurst. It is not hard to find. The veins of public transportation run through it like blood through the body of the city, and the trains clatter along the tracks in their ceaseless rhythm. You’ll find yourself in the heart of the city, amidst its urban cadence and the ever-watchful gaze of its towering edifices. As you walk the streets, you’ll see storefronts adorned with bright signs and the delicate calligraphy of a distant land. For in these past decades, many from across the vast reaches of Asia have come to make this place their own. At every turn, there’s a market or a laundromat, their doors open to the hurrying throngs, and the air is rich with the scent of spices and the chatter of languages. These shops are beloved by the locals for their bounty, their prices, and the ease with which they weave into the lives of those who dwell here. Just a stone’s throw from where I stand, four markets line the street, each a testament to the neighborhood’s newfound heritage.

But Bensonhurst is more than this. It is a tapestry of lives, stitched together by the hands of immigrants, their children, and their children’s children. And though the larger businesses may bear the mark of Asian ownership, the park nearby, newly touched by the hand of renovation, offers a place for all. There stand basketball courts, fields for the games of soccer and baseball, and swings where children’s laughter dances on the wind. Here, the water fountain sparkles under the summer sun, a brief respite from the city’s heat. And you’ll see the colors of the world in the faces that gather there, united in play and the common language of joy.

In this place, the sky is not broken by the hard lines of corporate towers. Instead, the buildings are homes, co-ops and condominiums, two-family houses where life spills out into the streets. The people are friendly, their voices a constant hum in the air, yet the roar of engines and the blare of music are their heralds, echoing through the dawn and into the night. Come nightfall, tread with care, for though the streets are safe, the hearts of men are ever unpredictable. There are those who might seek mischief, the bullies and the thieves who haunt the shadows. I have felt their malice in years past, yet time has softened their blows. But the thieves remain, their eyes set upon the packages left unguarded.

And there is the matter of dogs. Their presence is marked not by their barking, but by the leavings they scatter upon the sidewalks. The city demands their owners clean the mess, but the rule is often ignored. It is a small thing, yet it rankles, a reminder of the city's untamed spirit. As you walk, watch your step, and keep your shoes clean, for the streets of Bensonhurst are as wild as they are welcoming.

The first thing a soul must reckon with about Portland, Oregon, is the meaning of "weird." There's a saying daubed on the backside of a building that juggles the trifecta of pizza, liquor, and music, with a foot in the shadows of law's good graces, and it reads "Keep Portland Weird." To some, it's a whispered echo of the Portland of the nineties and early aughts, a time when it was a quieter place, less burdened by fame's high price, a crucible of strange and wondrous subcultures. To others, it's a siren's call to the quirky and the odd, a place where "weird" is a crown to wear, not a scarlet letter. Despite the tide of wealth from Californian shores and the rise of steel and glass to house them, Portland holds fast to its weirdness. Weird doesn't equate to universal acceptance, but rather a tolerance for the unusual, the peculiar. It does not shun the comforts of modernity nor the battles they wage. Like every corner of this vast country, our shelves are stocked with goods from distant lands. There are myriad paths to strangeness, to deviation from the norm, yet Portland is rife with the ordinary. Yoga mats unfurl beneath hipsters and suits alike. Perhaps in Portland, weirdness means we dance through the mundane with a lighter step. In the neighborhood where I dwell, as in many corners of this city, there are homes ablaze with color, gardens tended with care, and in the summer, boxes left for free on the sidewalks. These boxes, more often than not, are humble cardboard vessels of discarded items, yet they hold something mystical, a boon for the passerby who dares to look. They brim with clothes and tomes but could contain anything. This serendipity of wandering through Southeast Portland captures its essence. At least, it does for me, though I am but one shade of weird among a spectrum. There are those among us who wouldn't deign to dress from a box on the street. They find joy amidst bleating goats in yoga or in the roar of the Timbers' faithful. Portland teems with souls chasing their dreams or dreaming within the amber haze of barroom light. Yes, Portland wrestles with its demons, the grip of substances a symptom of deeper wounds, perhaps exacerbated by the endless drizzle and sullen skies. There is a specter of homelessness too, a puzzle without a solver. The city's open arms, more generous than most, draw them near, but even here, the help falls short. The housed walk a line between compassion and disdain. In this, we are no stranger than any other place.

The mountains loom eternal, an ancient witness to the sun's path, morning to night. They stand, immutable and indifferent to the whirl of human concerns, a steadfast presence against the fleeting moments of life. Oftentimes, in the thick of daily toil and turmoil, they fade from my mind, yet they remain, silent and stalwart. On days when the weight of the world bears down, they call out to be seen, and I turn to them. They offer solace to my weary spirit, a quiet strength urging me onward, step by step. 

I came to this place when my scholarly journey began, drawn by the mountains that guard the northern edge of the campus. The university itself boasts wonders in its edifices and ponds and trees, each staking a claim on my heart, yet it is the mountains that hold dominion. The town sprawls in its own beauty, a mosaic of cafes where time melts away in caffeinated frenzy. Venture further and the downtown wraps around you, its faded brick and mortar echoing a bygone era, a testament to the bustle and vigor that rivals the neighboring metropolis. 

But this fervor is fleeting, giving way to the tranquil embrace of the small town, past the library's solemn walls. This duality, so close yet worlds apart, imbues the city with a mystique that begs exploration. Here, memories weave themselves into the fabric of the streets, each tied to a place. The rusted swings of the park, the hurried dash through downtown to the theater, the university's gift of cinema. Yet, like all places in life, it is home to shadows as well. The ponds, a sanctuary for contemplation, bear witness to tears shed in the silent hours of night, in the throes of existential dread. 

I have found myself there often, pondering the turtles and ducks, each creature playing its part in the grand tapestry of existence. I wondered then, lost in the labyrinth of life, about my own place and purpose. I walked on, past the pond, the park, the suburbia's quiet houses, until I reached the main street. There, the sun cast its golden light upon the palm trees, painting the sky in hues of dawn, and I looked up to see I was heading north. And there they were, as ever, the towering mountains brushing the heavens with their ancient peaks, voiceless yet stirring within me a resolve as old as the earth itself.

You might pass it by at first, your eyes skimming over the unremarkable facade of a residential district set behind a strip of stores. It's not the kind of place that leaps out as a place to live, and certainly not one that most would choose to call home. Yet if you wander past the old Whole Foods, its doors long closed to the world, and slip behind the hotels that stir to life but once a year, you'll stumble upon a lively community unknown to the unseeing eye. These streets are lined with apartment complexes, assembled with the precision of Russian dolls, each one placed carefully beside the other in a row that stretches down the road like a tale being told in chapters. The first buildings you come upon have gained notoriety for unsavory affairs, tales best left untold, for appearances can deceive. But there are other complexes, worlds unto themselves, their existence a secret kept from the larger world. Across from these apartments stands a satellite campus of a community college, the buildings quiet and unassuming, where students shuffle in with coffee in hand, sleep still clinging to their eyes at the break of day. The gates groan open to admit them, while irate drivers bemoan the delay in their morning commute, the sound of their frustration echoing in the still air. The road meets another residential street, where a park shares a corner with a rehabilitation center for the broken-bodied. The center, with its inviting porch and languid ceiling fan, seems to breathe in the heavy summer air. Children play in the park across the way, their laughter rising above the hum of bees amongst the flowers by the roadside. Retirees walk their dogs along the path, casting disapproving glances at the skateboarders and nodding at the teenage girls who whisper secrets by the swings. Beside the park, a sushi place offers modest fare to few patrons, flanked by a swimming supply store and a nail salon, each a cog in the wheel of the strip mall's charm. Here one could attend to the season's needs all at once—fill a pool, polish nails, and savor hibachi chicken. A frozen yogurt shop invites the youth, who navigate the park with cups in hand, their toppings melting in the sun's embrace as they ride their boards and exhale vapor into the heat. This neighborhood, a slice of Americana, holds fast to its history in the somnolent South, where change comes as slowly as the turning of the earth.

In the place where I live, there's a peculiar rhythm that clings to the bones of the earth. The houses stand solitary, mostly, though here and there you find one cleaved into two like a great beast bisected, yet still tethered together. My own dwelling has a patch of earth for a yard and a narrow strip of pavement for a drive. It is a remnant of a time not so distant when the suburbs were the promise of a new world, a dream woven into the fabric of the American vision. Once, this promise held the people in its embrace, but now it seems to slip away. Yet our neighborhood endures, a testament to dreams that refuse to die, voices still calling to those who wander through, whispering that the dream lingers still, though perhaps more tenuously than before.

The folks here don't carry the same spark of hope as once they did. The tidy patches of green have grown weary, but cars still rest in the drives, and the children, unaware, play as though the world they know is the only one that matters. The old school, standing for nearly ninety years, remains a structure of hope for the young, a vessel of memory for the elders. Churches are sparse, their pews often empty, but the courts echo with the sound of basketballs and laughter. Each home has its own face but shares a common soul.

A great supermarket, Super "A", stands, run by a Yemeni family, perhaps the only Arabs among us. The community is largely African American, the streets generous in their width, where children play their games, pausing only for the passing cars. Generations have settled here, people who can spin tales of a time when every face was familiar. A karate school once flourished, but with the waning of Hollywood's martial arts tales, it vanished, replaced by a pharmacy, for medicines are the new talismans, or so they say. There's a small theater showing films of yesteryear, a sanctuary for the old who find solace in the stories of the past, a place where they can escape without the clamor of youth.

An expressway cuts through the town, though its entrance and exit lie beyond our borders. There was talk once of petitioning for our own access, the younger ones eager, the elders wary. The threat of change and the wisdom of age led to its rejection, preserving a way of life they feared would be lost. Now, a new high school rises, and we ponder what symbol shall represent us. I reckon a cyborg with a drawl and a log cabin might just capture the spirit of this place.

In the sprawling expanse of the city, where the towers rise like ancient sentinels and the streets weave a labyrinthine course through the heart of human enterprise, my neighborhood stands, a mosaic of disparate lives and ambitions. Here, the domiciles scatter themselves with a randomness that seems ordained by some capricious hand, interspersed with the commerce of men, their offices and shops, their eateries and theaters, all clamoring for space and attention. There is no end to the newness of restaurants, the novelty of stores, each one a testament to the ceaseless churn of society's appetite. The thoroughfares are lined with establishments both grand and obscure, the mighty chains of corporations standing shoulder to shoulder with the humble boutiques, each a sanctuary for the curious and the jaded alike.

The streets themselves, a testament to the city's ceaseless pulse, gird quiet enclaves that might have known serenity were they not encircled by such relentless activity. Parks, sparse yet treasured, offer a refuge where the young are brought to frolic under the watchful eyes of their guardians. And the people, oh the people, a tapestry of humanity woven from threads of every hue and creed. Within a stone's throw, the vibrant embrace of the LGBTQ+ community stands alongside the devout lives of Orthodox Jews, while those who fled the shadows of the old Soviet lands seek a new dawn here.

Beyond, the city's great expanse unfurls more enclaves, each a world unto itself. Korea town, China town, Little Armenia, each a bastion of culture and history, yet the road to these places is a trial in itself, for the city's veins are clogged with the lifeblood of its denizens, a mere ten miles a marathon of endurance through the gridlocked arteries of asphalt.

In this city, few tread the paths that once bore the weight of footfalls. The distances are vast, the hearts weary, and the preference is for wheels over soles. Thus, the city chokes on its own growth, the new edifices rising in defiance of the limits, promising homes yet bringing only the specter of further congestion. And yet, within this urban sprawl, the homes themselves bear witness to life's diversity. From the towering apartments to the modest homes, the duplexes and condominiums, each stands as a testament to the varied aspirations of its inhabitants.

The people too, a multitude of ages and stories, yet I find myself a stranger among them, the bonds of community frayed by the passage of time. The memories linger still, of childhood days spent in the company of neighbors, the laughter shared and the innocence preserved. But now, the ties that bound us have loosened, and we are left adrift in this vast sea, each of us a solitary island in a city that never sleeps.

Where is everything she asked as we passed the cornfields that stretched out to the horizon. This is it I said with the knowing that she’d be taken aback by the vastness and the emptiness of the land. She was from a place where the grocery store was but a short walk from her door and she’d never seen such open space in all her life. I told her of what it was to grow up in the rural heart of Ohio and in that telling she came to know what I was and where I came from. The country road was two lanes wide and it led to a quarry filled with water. Beyond it lay the small development where I lived. Brick and stucco houses stood solitary on their half-acre plots where the people took pride in their keeping. In the springtime the flowers bloomed and the trees of the Midwest changed with the seasons. Driveways held the finest Mercedes Benz cars that gleamed under the midday sun after a good washing. Down the road toward my grey stucco home my Korean neighbor stood outside with a friendly face. He spent his days mowing his lawn and his singing rose above the hum of the mower. The neighborhood laughed with him for he was a genuine soul with a past of his own. He had grown older and his wits had dulled with time. Once he’d been a doctor but now he blended in with the grass and his John Deere mower. At last you’ll find my home. Geese abound in the side yard with our Terrier in chase. In the back a stream fed into the quarry and there you could hear the bullfrogs and the water and sometimes the lowing of cows from distant farms. Across a bridge of wood was an untouched place where trees and herbs and wildflowers grew as they would. Here was where my childhood played out. We built forts in the trees and hunted animals that were mostly just chased away and there was ever a neighborhood child for company. The winters in that small town could be harsh but they held a beauty all their own. The yard turned from a sea of green to a barren wilderness. The trees that had borne flowers of pink and purple and orange became skeletons of bark. When the snow came it was a wonderland that appeared by night’s end. The backyard was littered with snow angels my sister had made and snowmen stood guard. My sister and I fought often as children and in winter our weapon was the snowball. We built great forts like igloos to store our ammo and branches for our arsenal. In that wonderland we played and pretended and for a time nothing else mattered. We were just children without a care in the world.
